titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The ground was this morning covered with snow, which it has scarcely been through the whole Winter.— Day spent as usual on Sundays. In the afternoon the young Countess Neale came to tea with Mrs: Adams. No writing this day.

2. Weather fine though still somewhat cold. Evening at the Princess Henry’s party. Cards with the Countess Blumenthal, Mademoiselle d’Otterstaedt and the Baron d’Engestrom— He told me he had written to Sweden upon the subject that I mentioned to him the other day at Court.— Mrs: Adams passed the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s, where after the party was over, I went and took her.

3. Called this morning on the Count Neale, and gave him the information concerning his affair contained in the letter I last received from Mr: King, with which he was much pleased.— Dined at Mr: Schickler’s. The company smaller than usual. Among the rest was the famous Swedish Baron Armfeldt. He appears to be much out of health. Had some conversation with M. de Maisonneuve. Mr: Richards with us this Evening.— Embarassments of various kinds.— At the Casino, an hour in the afternoon.

4. Went round with Mr: Richards this morning, to several magazines of furniture.— Shall wait for further certainty how long I am to stay here.— Miss Neale spent the afternoon and Evening with Mrs: Adams who was ill great part of the day with the head ache.

5. Walk in the morning with Mrs: Adams.— And in the Park.— Count Neale called on me— Afternoon at the Casino.— Weather warm— Find myself in a state of suspense and embarassment to which I am not unaccustomed— I know not whether I am to remain here longer or return home.— And just at this moment, I have opportunities for the purchase of furniture.

6. Went to look at the furniture which Miss Schultz has to dispose of.— Walk under the trees.— In the Evening we went to the sacred Concert at the Opera house.— It was an Oratorio, called the Death of Jesus, written by Ramler, and the music composed by Graun. It is performed here on Good Friday every year.— The house was extremely full. Looked in upon the Theatre of the Opera, which is very beautiful and built with great taste. Frederic the 2d: who erected the building used to give several Operas every winter in it at his own expence. The late king followed the example for several of the first years of his reign. But for the last two or three years the practice has been discontinued, and it is doubtful whether it will be renewed by the present king. The inscription in the front of the Opera-house is “Fredericus Rex, Apollini et Muses.”

7. The forenoon passed in attention to small concerns.— Strolled about in the park. My brother dined out. Evening, concluded reading the Comedy of Errors, the last of Shakspeare’s Comedies in the Edition which I now use— Miss Neale here a short time in the afternoon.

8. Easter day.— The weather very fine— Walk with Mrs: Adams in the Park, where in the afternoon several thousand persons from the town resorted.— Walk under the trees in the Evening.— the Young Countess Neale here at tea.— I continue my study of German, but make in it a very slow progress.
9. Letter to Mr: King.— Received one from Mr: Murray. In the afternoon at the Casino. Saw Baron Engeström there; and Mr: Knoblauch.— Evening, latter part at Doctor Brown’s.
10. In the morning at Mr: Schickler’s. Afterwards went with Meyer, to look at some furniture. Walk in the Park.— Evening at home reading Macbeth.— Weather fine, but cold.
11. Weather still fine. Wrote Mr: Murray.— Walk in the Park. at the Casino this afternoon. On returning home found Miss Neale.— Finished Macbeth.

12. Wrote a little in the morning. From noon till 2 at Prince Radziwill’s concert. He sings very well himself.— Prince Zouboff thinks himself a performer on the violin, and makes as many grimaces as his monkey of famous memory. The hereditary Prince & Princess of Orange were at the Concert. At the Casino, after dinner.— Evening, King John.

13. Writing to the Secretary of State.— Miss Neale, Mrs: Brown and her daughter here this afternoon. The latter to Tea.— Purchased Mirabeau’s book upon the Prussian Monarchy under Frederic the 2d: and the works of Frederic. Began to read the first. Though I must deduct some part of the time which I have devoted to the study of German for this perusal.— King John, this Evening.

14. Baron Engeström called on me in the forenoon. Conversation on the subject of the late french decree against neutral Commerce— He says that the Baron de Göertz was the author of the secret history of the armed neutrality.— Mrs: A. went to tea at the Countess Brühl’s.— Went and signed the agreement with Mr: Cohen to take his apartments. At the Casino, two or three hours.

15. Weather has been fine and clear these ten days. Now grown quite warm— Walk with Mrs: A. before dinner in the Park.— And again alone towards evening. Mademoiselle Neale at tea. Dull, heavy and languid as the spring advances.

16. Attended this morning a sale of furniture, but met with nothing to suit me. Weather warm as summer. Evening at the Princess Henry’s party.— Princess Louis there. Whist with Madame de Blumenthal, Mlle: d’Otterstaedt, and Count Razumoffsky.— Observed the Marquis de Lucchesini. Mrs: Adams spent the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s.

17. Weather very warm still. Streets and roads excessively dusty. There is no medium in this Country, between mud and dust.— Walk in the Park.— Mlle: Neale, this afternoon.— At the Casino.— Moniteur.— Tis a thankless and always unpleasant task to read these papers.— It affects my humour.

18. Visit this forenoon to Mr: Engeström, Found there the Marquis Parella, Baron de Brentano and Count Unruh. Madame d’Engeström is a Polish Lady.— Some rain this afternoon, after a fortnight of fine, and remarkably warm weather. Mademoiselle Neale pass’d the Evening with Mrs: Adams.— Two hours at the Casino.

19. Letter from Mr: Murray with a New-York paper of 10 February.— Weather still warm.— Usual walk in the Park, and in the afternoon at the Casino.— Have not yet abandoned my study of German, though my progress is almost imperceptible.— Finished reading King John, and began King Richard the 2d:—in the Evening.

20. Letter to Mr: Murray.— Walk not so long as usual.— Mlle: Neale and the Miss Brown’s in the afternoon and Evening.— At the Casino— Such a collection of French, English and German newspapers and periodical pamphlets that it is scarcely possible to peruse them with methodical order. Use the German as much as I can, to acquire the language.

21. In the uniformity of my present life it is scarcely possible to notice any thing distinguishing one day from another. Walk in town this day instead of the Park. At the Casino. and the Evening reading Richard the 2d:

22. Sunday morning occupation.— My brother unwell.— Walk round the park or Thiergarten.— A walk very much frequented on Sundays.— At the Casino in the afternoon. Mlle: Neale. Finished Richard the 2d: in the Evening. Weather very fine.
23. Went this morning to look at some furniture for sale at auction to-morrow. Mrs: Brown and her daughter at tea.— Reading 1st: part of Henry 4th: in the Evening.

24. Attended the sale of furniture, but made no purchase.— In the Evening at Prince Radziwill’s, to see a couple of french plays performed. Le bon ménage, and Les precieuses ridicules. The performers were, the Prince, M. de Maisonneuve, M. & Madame de Sartoris and their two children, Mlle: Neale and Mlle: de Borch, with some others. The acting was remarkably good. That of M. de Maisonneuve especially. Sat by Prince Reuss and had some conversation with him, upon music and German literature.
25. At the sale of furniture again this day, and to as little purpose as yesterday. Mlle. Neale in the afternoon. At the Casino— English and french newspapers. Continuation of Henry 4th:—1st: part.

26. At Prince Radziwill’s concert in the forenoon. Two setts of different music, to Bürger’s Lenore, one printed, and the other in manuscript.— An excellent piece of catholic church music. O! Salutaris Hostia.— Afternoon at the Casino, and Evening at Doctor Brown’s.— Finished 1st: part of Henry 4th.

27. Attended a sale of furniture again. Mrs: Adams went with Mrs: Brown, to Charlottenburg in the morning. Was taken unwell in the afternoon.— It is of no use, but rather a misfortune to foresee evils which can neither be remedied nor prevented.— Walk after dinner. At the Casino. Miss Browns, and Miss Estoff in the Evening. Began the 2d: part of Henry the 4th:

28. Weather warm. Walk in the park along by the river. Mrs: A. continues unwell. At the Casino, afternoon. Reading German papers. Three quarters of my life have been spent in learning languages, and I know but two, tolerably well: Read a little Shakspeare in the Evening.

29. The morning exercises as usual.— Dined at the Grand Marshall, Count Podewils’s; a large company, and splendid dinner. Sat next to the Marquis de Musquitz.— Walk in the afternoon. Letters from Mr: King and Mr: Murray. Public and private concerns, threaten alike the heaviest disasters and calamities.

30. Letters from Pitcairn at Hamburg, covering one from my mother at Philadelphia. 10. Feby. Several Ladies with Mrs: A. at tea, this afternoon.— At the Princess Henry’s.— Cards. Whist with the Countess Blumenthal, Mlle: d’Otterstädt, and Baron de Stakelberg.

Day. Rise at about 7. Study German till 1/2 past nine. Breakfast— Write till 2. Walk out till 3. Dine— Pass an hour at the Casino, and the remainder of the Evening at home, generally reading Shakspeare.— I can perceive some small progress in the acquisition of the German language. I read with more facility than when I first began. Yet it is a dull and tedious kind of application, and it prevents me from obtaining any knowledge more substantial than that of words, by engrossing so much of my time.
